author: Adam Kurkjian
title: Jonathan Kraft says he holds no ill will toward Jim Irsay | The Blitz |
text:
For as much vitriol that has been passed back and forth between the Colts and Patriots over the years, ascending to its highest point this offseason in light of the former turning in the latter to the league on a deflated balls scandal from the AFC title game, Pats president Jonathan Kraft insists there's no ill will toward Colts owner Jim Irsay.
"I'm going to tell you, Jim's dad, (deceased former Colts owner) Bob, actually gave me a stock tip, I don't know, probably about the first or second time I've ever met him, a little Midwestern bank, and it ended up being a great stock," Kraft said on a pregame show on 98.5 The Sports Hub.
"That started us out on good footing, and, look, we're all partners in the NFL," Kraft added. "Partnerships, partners, in any type of business, you have good moments, you have bad moments, but you're partners. I think Jimmy's been, before that, his dad, Bob, have been partners of our families for 22 years. You go through good times, bad times, but at the end of the day, it's a partnership."
As far as the possibility for the Patriots losing a home game to an international contest, Kraft said that's a possibility.
"Fortunately for the league, there have been enough teams that have been willing to give up a home game," he said, "but the league has the right to take one home game from each team in the league, I want to say over the next 15 years, but I could be wrong on the time frame, and ask you to host the game overseas. We would prefer not to do it, but hopefully it doesn't come down to that."
